awd_titl_txt: Charge regulation in metalloproteins: from electron transfer to self-assembly.
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Bryan Shaw from Baylor University to investigate how the net electrostatic charge of proteins, Z, is affected by biochemical processes such as electron transfer. Most naturally-occurring proteins have a net electrostatic charge at neutral pH, that is an imbalance in the number of positively- and negatively-charged chemical groups of the protein.  This net charge may affect many chemical processes involving proteins, such as electron transfer or protein aggregation. However, the charge Z at physiological pH has been measured for very few proteins. The lack of accurate measurements of Z may obscure a rigorous understanding of basic biochemistry; the knowledge of Z may create opportunities to chemically manipulate electrostatic forces inside living cells.  Dr. Shaw's research group is using one of the very few tools available to rapidly measure Z to study how the net charge of a proteins is affected by electron transfer, molecular crowding, and protein aggregation and is also designing small molecules that can affect the electrostatic properties of proteins inside living cells.   Dr. Shaw develops "mouth models" to enable students who are blind to use their touch and taste to visualize the structure and charge of proteins (Patent No. 10,043,413 B2). The mouth models are bite-sized exact 3D replicas of known proteins made of edible material.  Students sense the structure of the model by placing the model in their mouth instead of sensing the model with their fingers.

This research project seeks to answer the following scientific questions: how and why do metalloproteins regulate net charge during single electron transfer? When two proteins approach one another in solution to form a stable or transient complex (or to crowd), does the net charge of each protein affect the other's net charge by the magnitude predicted by theory? Can the electric field of a highly-charged protein alter the activity of a metalloenzyme with which it interacts? These questions are being addressed by measuring the net charge Z of folded proteins under various conditions using "protein charge ladders" and capillary electrophoresis. The new knowledge is applied to the design and chemical synthesis of aryl ester molecules that can selectively amplify the net charge of proteins via lysine acylation. These "charge boosting" molecules are designed to make possible electrostatic control the self-assembly of proteins into amyloid-like fibrils. The results of this research will deepen our fundamental understanding of the electrostatic forces in biological chemistry and to test the possibility that these forces can be chemically manipulated inside living cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on two themes in biochemical science: 1) carrying out experiments to increase our knowledge of fundamental and applied protein electrostatics, and 2) public outreach to make imagery and data in the chemical sciences accessible to people with blindness and low vision. In summary, the project successfully tested each hypothesis presented in the original proposal and developed new tools to help people with blindness visualize data using various tactile senses. In order to enable data sharing between sighted and blind persons, the project also developed a hybrid data format that can be visualized by eyesight or tactile sensing. The successful testing of the proposed hypotheses (and publication in high impact journals) and successful adaptation of the outreach efforts by blind scientists demonstrated the intellectual merits of the proposed work and final outcome.

In the laboratory, researchers were able to chemically cross link proteins at short distances (less than 1 nm) that mimicked their crowding in a cellular environment. With this crowding in effect, researchers were able to determine how the enzymatic activity and net charge of a particular protein was affected by the crowding of its nearest neighbor. Researchers were also able to determine how proteins regulated their net charge during proton coupled electron transfer. Here, researchers demonstrated that a single proton can act as an electrostatic shield during electron transfer, to prevent the protein from adjusting its net charge in response to changing metal oxidation states. In other words, the net charge of some proteins will never change (is isoelectric) during proton coupled electron transfer. Researchers also successfully synthesized and tested small organic molecules that can selectively “supercharge” misfolded proteins. For example, small "ball and chain molecular maces" were created to selectively boost the net negative charge of amyloid forms of proteins. This type of charge boosting diminished the propagation of misfolded proteins.

The outreach efforts of the project were highly successful, and garnered national and international news coverage. Here, the project created new tools and data formats to help people visualize data regardless of their level of eyesight. The first breakthrough involved using the mouth (lips and tongue) as tactile sensors to visualize small bite-size molecular models. Using high resolution 3D printing or silicone injection molding, tiny models were fabricated from edible material (gelatin) or non-edible dental resin. The models were exact replicas of proteins from the protein data bank and varied in size from that of a rice grain to that of a peanut. Some students were able to discriminate between different protein conformers more accurately with their mouth than with their hands. Researchers also introduced the idea of using an ancient artform, the lithophane, to create data formats that can be shared between blind and sighted persons. Here, 3D printing is used to convert digital 2D images into thin translucent tactile graphics that light up with picture perfect resolution when held up to ambient light. These data types allowed students and researchers with and without eyesight to “sit around and talk about the exact same piece of data.” For these efforts, the principal investigator and several of the blind and visually impaired co-authors were featured in national news media, including National Public Radio’s All Things Considered https://www.npr.org/2022/08/19/1118521010/this-technology-makes-data-accessible-to-blind-and-visually-impaired-people

The project was also highlighted and researchers were interviewed by Science magazine. https://www.science.org/content/article/how-3d-printing-could-help-blind-researchers-see-data

The impact of the laboratory-based research and outreach-based research will be broad. The use of chemical crosslinkers to search for nearest neighbor electrostatic effects in protein crowding can be used on virtually any protein of interest. The finding that the net electrostatic charge of a protein is a putative chemical target might lead to new types of “charge boosting” drugs. The impact of the outreach-based research to improve data visualization for blind persons will extend beyond science. Although researchers developed the oral-based visualization tools, and lithophane based tools for science, they can be used to tactilely visualize any type of 3D or 2D image whether the image is related to science, engineering, mathematics, art, business, medicine, economics, any of the humanities, or law.
